utterances: In a bearish economy, we're in the midst of a very bullish art market.
The record for a Claude Monet painting was shattered at Christie's in London yesterday when one of his water lilies paintings sold for more than $80 million.
Last month, a work by Lucien Freud fetched more than $33 million - the most paid for a work by a living artist.
And a Francis Bacon triptych went for more than $86 million.
[POST-BROADCAST CORRECTION: The $33 million paid for the work by Lucien Freud was the most paid for such a work AT AUCTION.
The Jasper Johns painting ""False Start"" sold for $80 million in 2006.]
NPR's Elizabeth Blair paid a visit to a collector.
When you step off the elevator to Aaron Levine's law office, the first thing you see is art - 10 large prints bursting with color, pastel and fluorescent pinks and yellows.
On closer inspection, you see that at the center of each print is an electric chair.
People don't know that they're Andy Warhols, and when they ask I tell them these are clients whose cases I lost.
His wry sense of humor aside, Aaron Levine is a trial lawyer who has successfully sued pharmaceutical companies for the past four decades.
In his spare time, he and his wife are serious collectors.
Works by Warhol, Jasper Johns, Roy Lichtenstein and dozens of other established artists grace the walls - and that's just his office.
Aaron Levine says the economic downturn has not affected his collecting, and he doesn't think he's alone.
He went to Art Basel, the big art fair in Switzerland earlier this month.
I don't see from my recent trip any lessening in the ferociousness of the contemporary art collector, nor their pocketbook.
But he did notice one difference.
In Basel, it used to be one-third Americans, and now it's about 10 percent Americans.
One reason could be the weak dollar.
The other: new wealth overseas.

It seems that a very small group of ultra-rich buyers is keeping the high-end art market alive, says Josh Baer, a private dealer, who writes the arts industry blog ""The Baer Faxt."" He says the new collectors are from Russia, Asia, India and other places.
Five or 10 years ago, they had nothing on their walls.
The American collectors, the major ones, have been collecting for 20, 30, 40 years.
So they already have a number of masterworks themselves, so they're in less of a hurry to need to buy one more.
Take the Russian billionaire art lover Roman Abramovich.
He bought both the Lucien Freud and the Francis Bacon at auction last month for about $120 million.
In other words, even though fewer people are bidding, those who are have enough money to drive prices way up.
And while that's gotten a lot of attention, it is not the whole story.
The art market is going in two directions.
Ian Peck, president of the Art Capital Group, says the auction houses hold separate sales based on price.
The part one sales are million-dollar-plus works, and the part two sales are anywhere from a few thousand up to a million, let's say.
And if you compare the two, there's much, much greater weakness in the part two.
So, the high end is through the roof and the market for everything else is softening.
The economy is also affecting how purchases are made.
Peck's company, the Art Capital Group, lends money to people who want to buy art.
They use the artwork itself as collateral for the loan.
Peck says he's seen a 30 percent increase in the number of loan applications from this time last year.
One of the reasons we attribute is the economy, and that some people need liquidity to cover other investments that they have that may not be doing so well.
Of course, these are people who really aren't hurting financially.
So what does this all mean for average art lovers who get their art fix from museums?
Jonathan Fineberg is an art history professor at the University of Illinois.

Museums can no longer afford to buy the great works of art that should be available to the public because they've been consistently outbid by private individuals who are making huge amounts of money in the corporate world.
But Fineberg says you can't paint this with one stroke.
There are many excellent private collectors who routinely lend to public museums.
The public good, though, are hardly on the minds of folks at Sotheby's and Christie's.
Both are holding auctions in Paris and London this week, and there's no sign that the art market bubble is ready to burst.
Elizabeth Blair, NPR News.

Virginia's attorney general is a skeptic when it comes to global warming.
So when e-mails sent by climate scientists were leaked to the media last year, Ken Cuccinelli took note.
Critics thought the e-mails suggested deliberate manipulation of data.
And one of the scientists, Michael Mann, was a professor at the University of Virginia until 2005.

Since Mann was the recipient of public money for his research, Cuccinelli decided to investigate, and late last month demanded any documents or e-mails the university might have from Mann's time in Virginia.

The first time comic actor Chris Tucker visited Africa, he was promoting his movie ""Rush Hour."" At the time, he didn't see much beyond beautiful views from the upper floors of some of the continent's best hotels.
Three years ago, Tucker was invited back, this time as part of a delegation investigating Africa's AIDS crisis.
His traveling companions included former President Bill Clinton and rock star Bono.
Tucker was so moved by the poverty he saw on that trip, he's been working to help ever since.
Last weekend, he was part of the worldwide Africa awareness concert, Live 8.
He also wants to use his foundation to expand America's perceptions about the continent.
Most people just don't know.
They just know what they--you know, they know what's going on around in their lives, you know.
I didn't know until I traveled and I was fortunate enough to be on these trips with President Clinton and Bono and I found out.
I was, like, `Man this is terrible, you know.
What can we do about it?

So my whole thing is I want to do it--get a delegation, people like, you know, Magic Johnson, Michael Jordan, Tiger Woods, Serena Williams, Venus and my friends and get them to go out there with me so they could see--go through the clinics, go through the townships.
And, you know, when I was on a trip with Bono, then we went to a village with no clean water.
I couldn't imagine not having clean water.
I brush my teeth with bottled water sometimes, you know, in hotels.
I'm, like, `Man!
You know, I don't do that no more 'cause I don't want to waste water, because it was like--you know, I really appreciate certain things.
Now when you see some people in the w--I always thought growing up everybody in the world had clean water.
Everybody had food every day.
I never can imagine--you know, in some places in Somalia, you know, the land is dried up.
The water wells has been polluted 'cause animals die in them sometimes.
So then they have to walk miles and miles and hours and hours for fresh water.
I never even imagined that till I went on this trip and educated myself.
So I think that's the key, is to educate people, and that's why that concert was so important to put the awareness out there.

Hey, Chris, let me ask you this, and, again, I know that, frankly, before this came about, you've been out there touting the continent as a beautiful place to visit and wanting to help it, but there have been concerns that African-Americans in general have not done enough to help the continent of Africa.

There were cries that this, like the first Live Aid concert, was, quote, ""too white"" and that whites were behind the movement, not necessarily as a knock but the idea that black America isn't doing enough for, quote, ""their land."" What do you say to critics who suggest that?
Well, you know what?
I think it's, you know, sad to say but it's true.

I had this conversation with Bono and he told me, he said, `Listen, I'm from Ireland, and, you know, I want some people, especially African-Americans, to get involved with, you know, this fight for Africa because it's necessary.
And, me, personally, I think it's true.
I think that's the missing link, you know, because America--you know, we're in the most powerful country in the world.
And as African-Americans, we're connected with Africa more than any other race in America.
We have to.
That's why--that's one of the reasons why I want to get this foundation--my foundation to get this delegation together and go to Africa to educate people 'cause most people don't know.
